messageCorrelations.messagePreview: I was thinking maybe we could do something more low-key this time

annotation.label: Deflection through vagueness
annotation.text: Your HR rose 3 bpm and stress climbed from 23 to 27 when Jessica used vague language to redirect the trip conversation. HRV slipped from 47ms to 45ms. Your nervous system picked up the indirectness even if you did not consciously register it. This kind of slow-onset activation - where stress builds gradually rather than spiking - is the signature of unspoken tension. Your body sensed something was being avoided.

annotation.label: Self-silencing raises stress
annotation.text: Your HR climbed to 81 and stress jumped to 43 the moment you accommodated. HRV dropped to 38ms - a 24% decline from your 50ms baseline. This is a self-silencing pattern: the words say agreement but your body registers suppression. Accommodation language produced a sharper physiological response than the tension it was trying to defuse. Your nervous system knows when you are not saying what you actually think.

messageCorrelations.messagePreview: Are you sure? You seem like you have an opinion

annotation.label: Deflected bid for honesty
annotation.text: Jessica made a direct bid for your real feelings, and your HR still climbed to 88 with stress reaching 54. HRV sat at 34ms - deep in sympathetic territory. This was a moment where honesty could have released the pressure, but your body treated the invitation to be vulnerable as additional threat rather than relief. The stress peaked at 55 shortly after, suggesting the deflection cost more than the honesty would have.

overallInsight: This 10-minute conversation about spring break plans produced a distinctive slow-burn stress pattern. Unlike the sharp spikes in your conversation with Arthur, stress here built gradually and steadily - HR climbing from 64 to 88 bpm (a 37% increase) and HRV sliding from 50ms to 34ms (a 32% decrease) over the full duration without any single dramatic trigger. Stress rose from 18 to a peak of 55. The critical moments came at 5:00 when your accommodation language (saying 'whatever you want') pushed stress from 38 to 43 - your body registering the cost of self-silencing - and at 8:00 when Jessica directly asked for your real opinion and your stress still climbed to 54 rather than releasing. This pattern suggests that quiet emotional withdrawal is more physiologically taxing for you than open conflict. Your body took 6 minutes to begin recovering after the conversation ended, and the slow-burn nature of the activation means recovery takes longer because there was no single peak for your nervous system to process and release.
